description: From Ancient Greek ὁπλίτης (hoplítēs, “heavily armed foot-soldier”), from ὅπλον (hóplon, “arms, armor, weapon”) (from which English hopl-). Compare Latin hoplomachus (“gladiator”).

entries.meaning: (historical) A heavily-armed infantry soldier of Ancient Greece, wielding a one-handed spear and an aspis.
examples: […]  it was in the line of "hoplites" that the mass of citizen-soldiers were to be found.
